column1: The immune system mistakenly identifies a harmless substance as a threat, triggering an allergic reaction
Allergic reactions occur when IgE antibodies bind to mast cells and basophils, releasing histamine and other mediators
Histamine causes the typical symptoms of an allergic reaction, such as sneezing, itching, and swelling
Anaphylaxis is a severe, potentially life-threatening allergic reaction that affects multiple body systems simultaneously
Anaphylaxis is triggered by the same IgE-mediated pathway but affects the respiratory system, cardiovascular system, and skin more severely
Symptoms of anaphylaxis can include difficulty breathing, swelling of the throat, and a rapid drop in blood pressure
The rapid onset of anaphylaxis requires immediate medical intervention, often with epinephrine
Without treatment, anaphylaxis can be fatal, highlighting the importance of carrying an epinephrine auto-injector for those at risk
Understanding these mechanisms is crucial for diagnosing and managing allergic reactions and anaphylaxis effectively
Therefore, recognizing the signs of an allergic reaction and knowing how to respond is essential for preventing serious outcomes
The physiological mechanisms behind allergic reactions and anaphylaxis are complex but understanding them can save lives
